reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “value as product of factors” illustration and the associated inference that mostly-great futures are rare even conditional on high average performance. This matters to Section 2’s intuitive case for fragility, but it is not the whole argument for “no easy eutopia” (Section 2 also offers many concrete failure modes, and Section 3’s fussy-vs-easygoing analysis does not rely on Uniform(0,1)). So centrality is moderate. The objection is conceptually sound: a product-of-uniforms toy model does implicitly encode a substantive prior about factor distributions, and if factors are tightly concentrated near 1 the toy model’s extreme right-skew and rarity claims weaken. However, the critique mostly asserts (rather than argues) that abundance/institutions will push most morally relevant factors to 0.9–0.99, and it doesn’t engage other drivers of rarity in the paper (tail risks/near-zeroing factors, dependence structure, and value-efficiency fat tails). Hence only moderate strength. It is relevant to Forethought’s Tier-2 “eutopia is a narrow target / multiplicative fragility” thesis, but it’s a fairly standard modeling sensitivity point rather than a novel interaction or decisive internal tension, so relevance is mid-range. Overall, it modestly undercuts one illustrative support without seriously threatening the full position.
title: "Toy model assumptions skew the rarity of 'mostly-great' futures"
